unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Farmer's Harvest
question_text:
A farmer’s harvest of apples has a normal distribution with the distribution of individual apple weights $µ = 5\text{ ounces}$, and $σ = 0.5\text{ ounces}$.
Two apples are randomly chosen from this year’s harvest. The difference in the weights of the two apples is a normally distributed random variable.
What are the mean and standard deviation of this distribution of differences?
solution:
When two independent random variables (in this case, the two apple weights) are subtracted, take the difference of the means.

Since we are combining two identical distributions, the difference of the two means will be $(5)-(5) = 0$; thus, the new $µ = 0$. To calculate the standard deviation of the difference of two random variables, first add the variances of the individual distributions.

For this problem, the variance is the square of the standard deviation: ($0.5$)($0.5$) = $0.25$ for the original distribution. The new distribution, therefore, has a variance of $(0.25)+(0.25) = 0.5$.

To get the standard deviation of this new distribution of apple weight differences, take the square root of the new variance: $\sigma = \sqrt{0.5}$.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'D'.
